ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Statics, deformation, basic engineering concepts in terms of beam/truss design.
While I had already been exposed to some of the material already, I learned a lot about how different mechanical elements, such as beams, respond to various loadings.
I learned the basics of statics, a fundamental course in mechanical engineering.
Learned many of the fundamental analyses of structures that will be important to many courses and engineering pursuits in the future.
static forces and their deformations
I learned how to find all the loadings associated with beams and simple structures
I learned how to analyze structures under loads and determine their the support reactions, internal loadings, and subsequent deformation.
I learned about statics, structural analysis, stress and strain, deformation due to normal and shear stress, beam deflection, and other concepts important for mechanical engineering.
I learned a lot of content in this course about how to analyse structures and materials. This course is very comprehensive and well organised.
About statics and material loadings
I learned how to analyze static systems, and how to go about choosing the correct materials for the job at hand.
strength and deformation of static materials
A much better understanding of stresses and strains and engineering basics which are fundamental.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: well and clearly taught, follows textbook which is helpful for referencing
Weaknesses: a little dry, but that is to be expected
Strengths: Well taught and organized. Grading seems fair. Weaknesses: Not many weaknesses. Could maybe use some more videos/real-life applications.

The strength of this course is Prof. Qiu. She is incredibly organized and her lecture/notes are very clear. You can tell that she is always prepared for class. If you need help outside of class, there is plenty of support from ULAs and TAs, and Prof. Qiu will also help you herself during her office hours. She is also super understanding. I also really appreciated being able to have one page of any notes to bring to exams because it greatly reduced the stress during exams.  If you can, take MENG 280 with Prof. Qiu!

The material was very well organized and well taught but it would have helped to have recordings of the lecture so that it would be easier to listen back to the full analysis and derivation of certain problems rather than trying to figure it out from the notes.
Prof Qiu is a great lecturer, psets and exams directly reflect lecture content.
A strength is the course is very tied to the textbook so easy to follow. It could be improved with the classes being recorded as just looking at the notes is tough to follow.

The professor is really great - she actually explains things and hosts regular office hours to go over content. She is incredibly organized which makes the class easy to follow. 

One thing to change for next year might be to have more interactive example problems for later chapters, there were a lot at the beginning of the term but as the class got more tight with content some of that was cut.

This course has a very reasonable workload, and the classes are straightforward, engaging, and useful for the assignments. The exams are also fair and well written. No immediate weaknesses come to mind for this class.

I think this course was very well organized. The lectures had a good balance of theory and examples, the problem sets were related to what we had learned that week and gave good practice problems to better understand the material, and there were lots of resources (i.e. office hours, review sessions, etc.) to make sure we understood what was going on.
This is a great course, well planned, and builds on the knowledge of each prior unit.
Interesting class but hard exams
the class was amazingly structured and taught I have no complaints.
was taught very well

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. 280 is a solid class, one of the foundations for MENG students. You receive clear feedback on all the psets and midterms, and the course is well designed with more than enough office hours. The textbook is also useful as a reference and provides very clear background if you're ever confused on a concept. The material/lectures can be a little dry, but it is well taught - only complaint is Diana's chalk drawings can be slightly unclear sometimes. Overall, a very solid engineering class; I did enjoy it.

Yes. I think that this is a genuinely helpful course to think logically about structures and mechanisms in the world all around us. It might be hard to justify putting this amount of effort into a course that isn't for your major, but if they were interested in the subject, it would be a great choice.
This course is necessary to take for mechanical engineers.
Yes because it is necessary for engineering majors but could even be interesting for some physics students and since it is just all-around a great class.
Not the easiest class, but well organized and well taught
If it is required for the meche major it is a solid foundational course. If it is not for a major then it isnt necessary to take at all.
YES- especially with Professor Qiu. It is by far one of my favorite engineering classes I have taken so far. The content is interesting and it is well taught.

If you are taking this course, it is almost certainly because you are studying engineering and it is required. That being said, I thought this was a very enjoyable class, particularly with Professor Qiu.
Yes, if you're at all interested in engineering or mechanical design, take this course. It is a very good introduction to how structures react to various types of stress and is very well taught.
Yes, this is a great course for MechE majors and Professor Qiu is amazing.
If you are a mechanical engineering student
yes, but it was not easy
Yes, I think this class is vital for any engineer interested in static structures and especially Mechanical Engineers in general
